text:
When his brother had died, Wayne had known it would only be a matter of time before his sister-in-law would pack her bags and skip town, which was why he'd made sure she left the baby with him instead of dragging him around the country, sleeping in dodgy motels and the back of the car. The kid deserved a stable home, if nothing else, and, by God, when he'd held little Eddie in his arms for first time, he'd sworn to protect the boy, and if it was the last thing he did. They were family. They looked out for each other.

And it wasn't easy. Of course, it wasn't easy. Wayne had never expected it to be, but he did his damned best and he’d liked to think that they were doing alright.

When Eddie started coming home with bloodied noses and bruises, he was starting to worry. Kids could be cruel, he knew, but Eddie seemed to take it in stride, wearing his black eyes like badges of honour, and Wayne made sure they always had a well-stocked first aid kit at hand.

When Eddie started dealing drugs, Wayne worried even more, remembering his brother six feet underground, but Eddie was always careful about it, never getting into too much trouble, and using the money to help out where he could.

When Beverly Walker told Wayne's she'd seen Eddie kiss another guy, he wasn't even surprised, to be totally honest. Maybe he should have even expected it. Eddie had always been a little different, after all. And it wasn't an issue. Not for Wayne. So he made sure to let Eddie know that he had his back and to maybe not stick his tongue down a boys throat in plain sight in the future.

When they found the dead body of a cheerleader in their trailer and all of Hawkins started a manhunt for Eddie, Wayne did not have a single doubt in his heart that Eddie was innocent because, at the end of day, Eddie was a good kid, damnit. And then Eddie disappeared over spring break, and when he came back, he was changed. He tried to hide it, sure, the same wicked smile still gracing his face, the same restless energy still filling his eyes and his heart, but Wayne could see it in the quiet moments and the way he was almost never sober anymore, and he realised that his best wasn't good enough anymore and he was losing his nephew.

And then Steve fucking Harrington knocked on the door of their new trailer.

“Can I help you?”

“Er, hi, I’m – uhm – is Eddie in?“

“Shop’s closed.”

The boy blinked. “What?”

“Shop’s closed. If you're here to buy, you better come back some other time.”

“Oh, no. No, I'm not – I'm a friend.”

It took a lot to not laugh, to not show any reaction, to not slam the door in the boy’s face because who the hell did he think he was, anyway? And lying to Wayne’s face about it, too?

“He's through there.”

As much as Wayne hated to admit it, but Eddie got better afterwards. He no longer spent night and day in his trailer, no longer got high on his own supply, no longer stared into the middle distance as much as he had before, and Wayne was glad. He was. If having Steve Harrington in his trailer every once in a while, was the price for his nephew to be happy again, Wayne was more than willing to pay it.

And the thing was, he seemed to be having Steve Harrington in his trailer a lot these days.

“Didn't realise you were friends,” he said to Eddie one day after Steve had left.

Eddie shrugged, holding two beer cans in his hands and throwing one to Wayne. “We weren't. Now we are,” he answered, opening his can. “If that's alright with you, old man,” he added with a teasing smile, and Wayne raised his hands in surrender.

“As long as you know what you're doing.”

“Don't worry about me,” said Eddie, walking over to the couch.

“That's my job, boy.”

“Get a different job, then.”

And Wayne wasn't blind or anything, he could see what was happening here, could see the crush the size of Empire State Building Eddie was harbouring for this boy and his ridiculous hair, and he was worried because that was his job but also because he didn't want to see Eddie get hurt.

But he didn't say anything because it wasn't his place and he trusted Eddie to be smart about this and so instead Wayne kept his eyes and ears open and made sure to be there in case Eddie needed him.

It was just another regular day when Harrington came by once again. Eddie had been shutting himself off in his room all day, and Wayne had started to think that, maybe, something had happened the previous night, and when he saw the slightly crazed look on Harrington's face, he was almost certain about it.

“Er. Hi. Is –”

“In his room,” Wayne answered before Harrington could even finish his question, stepping aside to let the boy in, “You know the way.”

Harrington stepped inside, nodding in thanks at Wayne before knocking on Eddies door, and Wayne almost expected his boy to not answer, but he did.

“Come in!”

Steve pushed open the door and Wayne sat back down in his armchair, watching through the reflection in the mirror on the wall as Eddie appeared, his eyes wide in surprise.

“Hi,” Harrington said awkwardly, and Wayne raised the volume on the TV, if only to give the boys some semblance of privacy, but not enough to miss Eddie’s next words.

“Not gonna lie, I didn't think I'd see you again any time soon.”

“Yeah. Well.” Harrington cleared his throat. “Can I come in?”

And then the door to Eddie’s room closed and Wayne was left with the sound of the news he didn’t even want to watch.

Not that it did much. The paper-thin walls of the trailer weren't exactly made for being soundproof, and as much as Wayne tried not to listen, he couldn't help but catch the occasional snippets of their conversation. Enough to piece together what was going on.

“I’m sorry, okay?” Harrington’s voice sounded through to him, “I freaked out. I’m still kinda freaking out!”

It didn’t take a genius to figure out, and as much as Wayne believed that Eddie could hold his own, he was getting ready to jump in and do whatever he needed to do. Just in case.

But nothing happened.

Their voices lowered, became calmer. There was no sound of fighting, no sound of a struggle, no sound of anything but a civilised conversation.

Wayne strained his ears, trying not to feel too guilty about it. He was just looking out for his nephew, after all. But there was no sound coming from Eddie's room.

And so Wayne waited.

When Eddie's door finally opened again and his nephew emerged, heading straight for the fridge, Wayne had to keep himself from staring. Looking at Eddie, it was quite obvious just what they'd been doing in there, if the messy hair and rumpled shirt and swollen lips were anything to go by. Eddie, himself, seemed equally set on not acknowledging his uncle.

“So. Steve Harrington, huh?” Wayne's asked, unable to hold his tongue for much longer.

Eddie paused for a second, crouched in front of the fridge. “Yeah,” he said softly, retrieving two beers and straightening up.

“Make sure he treats you right.” He didn't trust that Harrington kid, truth be told.

“Don't worry about me,” Eddie told him, turning around, leaning back against the fridge.

“It's my –”

“Job. I know.” Eddie pushed off the fridge and crossed his arms, stepping a little closer to Wayne. “I'm fine.”

Wayne took a moment too look at the boy. He did seem fine. There was a glint in his eyes that had been missing for a long time now, Wayne had almost forgotten what it had looked like. Not that he would say that, of course.

“Should you leave your boy waiting like this?” he grumbled instead, turning back to the TV and almost expecting Eddie to leave. He didn't.

“Is this gonna be a problem?”

Frowning, Wayne looked back at Eddie. “What?”

“This.” Eddie gestured back at his room. “Steve. Me. Steve with me.”

“I already told you, I don't give two shits about –”

“I know,” Eddie cut him off, “But it's one thing to vaguely know that I get with guys when I'm out, and another thing all together to have it happen in literally the next room.”

Every once in a while, Wayne was taken by surprise at the guts Eddie had. There was zero fear in his face, zero shame. He wasn't trying to skirt around the topic, and Wayne appreciated that.

“Well then let me tell you again, a little clearer this time, that I don't care what you get up to with your boyfriend, or whatever he is. In fact, I'd rather you do it here, where it's safe, than out there where God knows what can happen. Understood?”

Eddie regarded him for a moment before nodding his head. “Understood,” he said, “Thanks.”

Wayne waved his hand dismissively and, this time, Eddie did turn to go back to his room, bringing the beers with him.

Wayne still wasn't quite sold on Harrington, but he meant what he'd said. As long as Eddie was happy and safe, Wayne was doing his job. In fact, it didn't even matter what he thought of Harrington, because this wasn't about him. This was about Eddie. This was about protecting his nephew. His family.

It wasn't until a few weeks later that Wayne thought, maybe, he'd gotten it all wrong.

He was coming home late, his body aching from the day, and he was almost surprised to see the faint light seeping through the cracks of the drawn blinds of the trailer, even more surprised to find Eddie and Harrington sitting on the couch together, Harrington leaning against Eddie's chest, craning his neck a little to smile at the other boy, their legs and hands entwined. Wayne didn't miss the way Harrington froze and tensed up when Wayne entered, the way his fingers twitched but he didn't pull away, the way his eyes grew wide as he stared up at Wayne.

“Boys,” he greeted them.

There was real fear I'm Harrington's face, as if he was only waiting for something to happen.

“Relax,” Eddie muttered into his ear, still loud enough for Wayne to hear, “He's cool.”

“Yeah, don't mind me.”

Harrington did relax a little, a least, though his eyes were still trailing Wayne as he made his way to the fridge for some beer.

“Need us to clear out?” Eddie asked.

“Nah. You stay where you are if you don't mind me joining in.”

“Knock yourself out, old man.”

Wayne took the old armchair, groaning a little as he settled into the cushions and opened the beer with a satisfying hiss. Eddie clearly didn't care that he was there, going back to playing with Harrington's hair, but the same couldn't be said about Harrington, and as much as Wayne still had his reservations about the boy, he couldn't stand the deer-caught-in-the-headlights look he had going on.

“Relax, son,” he said, taking a swig from his beer, “Ain't got nothing to fear from me.”

He didn't know this boy, obviously. Not really. But he had met Harrington Senior a couple times, enough to know that he wasn't exactly a pleasant person which mean he probably wasn't a pleasant father either and, goddamn it all, but this kid probably didn't even know better than to be scared for his life and ready to make a quick exit if need be. 

“In fact,” Wayne tagged on with a little sigh, “Our door’s always open for ya, alright? If you ever need a safe place to stay, or somethin’.”

Harrington's eyes grew a little wider but some of the fear receded, while Eddie shot Wayne a glance that was somewhere between grateful and frustrated.

Harrington cleared his throat. “Right. Thanks. Mr. Munson,” he said, a little unsteady, and grimaced at himself.

Wayne rolled his eyes. “Just call me Wayne like everyone else.”

“Right.”

Wayne went back to sipping his beer and trying not to be too obvious about watching the two boys.

Eddie started talking about a new campaign he'd planned for his club, his hands moving animatedly, and his face lit up in joy, and Harrington listened. It was quite obvious that he knew little about D&D but there was a fond smile on his face and he made sure to ask questions at just the right moments, keeping Eddie talking, and the more he did, the more Harrington relaxed, the more Wayne realised that maybe, just maybe, he'd been wrong about the boy. They looked comfortable like this. Familiar. And more importantly, Eddie looked really and truly happy. And whatever made Eddie happy was good enough for Wayne.

He left the boys to it, in the end, sitting on the couch and bickering in low voices, while he turned in for the night, but he did think, just before he closed his eyes and fell asleep, that he might be coming around to Harrington after all.

Dustin wasn’t jealous.

For almost a year he’d managed to keep both Steve and Eddie all to himself and separate from each other, thank you very much, because Steve and Eddie would never get along, would never find common ground, were so fundamentally different like day and night and could never, under any circumstances, exist in the same realm.

And then Chrissy Cunningham dies.

And then Eddie was on the run from the law and an angry mob.

And then Steve and Eddie and Nancy and Robin got trapped in the Upside Down.

And then they defeated Vecna and sealed off the Upside Down once and for all.

And now Steve and Eddie were apparently attached at the hip.

And Dustin wasn’t jealous. There was nothing to be jealous of. It was perfectly normal for them to want to be friends with someone their own age, someone they could smoke and drink and party with, someone they could talk about boring adult stuff with. In other words, someone who wasn’t Dustin.

It wasn’t that Steve and Eddie had friends other than Dustin that was the problem here. Steve had been friends with Robin for a while now and Dustin liked Robin, and Eddie had his band and they all seemed pretty cool. No, it was that Steve and Eddie were now apparently each other’s best friend and they’d forgotten all about Dustin in the process.

“Family Video, this is Steve, how can I help you?”

“Steve!”

“Henderson!” Steve asked, sounding actually happy to hear from him for once, “What’s up, man?”

“You. Me. Cinema. Tonight. 6:30.”

“Aww, man, I’m sorry, I can’t,” said Steve, sounding genuinely sorry, but at this point Dustin didn’t even care anymore, because this had been the fifth time in two weeks that Steve had blown him off.

“What? Why?”

“I’m hanging with Eddie.”

Of course you are, Dustin thought bitterly.

“So? He can come too.”

Steve let out a laugh and Dustin wasn’t sure if it was the connection, but it had sounded slightly hysterical. “Yeah, no, that’s not happening, short stuff.”

“Why not?”

“Because it just isn’t, okay?” Steve snapped, “Some other day. Not tonight.”

“Come one, Steve –”

“Look, I’m sorry, okay? I can give you a lift if you wanna go with someone else, but I can’t stay.” It sounded oddly final. Dustin was usually very good at making Steve agree to anything he wanted but something told him that that wouldn’t be happening here, and he didn’t understand why.

“Fine,” he snapped, “But don’t bother coming to me the next time you wanna cry about your lack of a dating life because I’ll be busy. I can’t tell you what I’ll be busy with. But I’ll be busy.”

“Oh, come on, man, don’t –”

“Have a nice day, Steve.” Dustin slammed the receiver down, nearly breaking the damn thing, and huffed. “Some other day, not tonight,” he grumbled in his best Steve impression, “Well, screw you too, Harrington!”

He ended up staying home that night, angrily leafing through several comic books at once, but not even Captain America could cheer him up.

And it kept happening, was the thing.

“Sorry, can someone else drive you to the arcade? I’ve got a. Thing.”

“Sorry I’m late, Eddie and I lost track of time.”

“Sorry I couldn’t be there, Eddie and I got drunk last night. Next time, though, eh?”

And it wasn’t like Eddie was any better. There had been little things, at first – He stopped hanging out with them as much after their campaigns, he started telling Dustin to please stop coming to the trailer unannounced, he gave the same lame-ass excused for why he couldn’t spend time with Dustin on that particular day – and then he cancelled D&D night.

“You can’t cancel D&D!” he all but shouted.

“It’s just the once,” Eddie explained calmly, “We’ll reschedule for the week after and we can make it a double session, alright? But this is important.”

“What could possibly be so important that you have to reschedule our campaign?”

Eddie opened his mouth as if to answer before stopping himself, his fingers fiddling with the rings on his hand. “I can’t tell you right now.” And that was the end of that particular conversation.

The worst part was that the others didn’t even seem to notice. Or if they did, they simply didn’t care.

“It’s not a big deal,” Mike had said with a shrug, and Lucas had agreed.

“Yeah, Dustin, relax. It’s just a game.”

Except it wasn’t about the stupid game, was it? It was about Eddie and Steve no longer wanting to spend time Dustin. And he didn’t understand why, didn’t understand what he’d done wrong, what had made them hate him like this. He was very aware that he could be a little loud, sometimes, a little rude, even. Annoying, probably. But he’d always thought that Steve and Eddie liked those things about him.

Apparently not.

So when the night of the cancelled D&D session rolled around, Dustin told his friends that he wouldn’t be coming to their sleepover in Mike’s basement and instead decided to go and see what Eddie was getting up to, lying in wait outside the trailer.

He didn’t have to wait for long.

A painfully familiar BMW rolled down the dirt track and stopped next to Eddie’s beat-up van, and out stepped stupid fucking Steve Harrington, with his stupid fucking hair, and his stupid fucking polo shirt, and Dustin wanted to scream. Of course, Eddie had blown them off for Steve. Of fucking course. Dustin wasn’t even sure anymore why it surprised him. It really shouldn’t. And even though he’d initially wanted to, Dustin couldn’t sit around and watch as his two best friends had a better time with each other than with him, so he left, and when he got home, he did scream, the sound muffled by his pillow, and if his eyes were a little puffy and red afterwards, no one had to know.

Dustin did not show up to the rescheduled campaign.

Dustin did not go to the next movie night.

Dustin stopped calling Steve at the store.

And it was fine. Everything was fine. Dustin was minding his own business, he was not sulking, he was not moping, and he was not jealous.

“Dustin!”

“What, mum?”

“Your friend is here!”

“Friend?” Dustin asked himself as he got off his bed, “What friend?”

And there, leaned against his car, stood Steve, his hands buried in the pockets of his trousers and a concerned expression on his face. “Hey, man, you okay?”

Dustin frowned. “What are you doing here?”

“I came to see you, dipshit. Since you’ve been avoiding me, or something.”

“Oh, yeah? I wonder why.”

“I do wonder why, actually!”

“I’m not the one whose avoiding you, Steve,” Dustin snapped, “You’re the one who stopped hanging out with me!”

Steve blinked. “What? No, I didn’t.”

“Er, yes you did,” Dustin argued, “And I can take a hint, okay? I mean you could have said something, but whatever. It’s fine. We’re cool. So now go away.”

He didn’t wait around to see if Steve really would go away, instead turning to go back into the house.

“Hey, now, wait a second!” Steve called after him, “Hey! Don’t walk away from me, Dustin!”

Something snapped and Dustin swiveled around “I said go away!” Dustin shouted, “Go and hang out with Eddie like I know you want to!”

A few passers-by had stopped on the street to look at them, and Steve stood frozen, his eyes wide as something like realisation dawned on his face. “Ah, shit, man,” he muttered, running a hand through his hair, “Look, can you, just – can you get in the car, please?” Dustin scoffed, crossing his arms. “Please?” Steve said again, his eyes almost nervously flitting around. “I’ll explain everything, I promise, but not here, okay? Just get in the car.”

Dustin kept his arms firmly crossed over his chest and wanted nothing more than to say no, except he really didn’t, because what he wanted was to get his friend back.

“Fine,” he huffed, walking around to the passenger door and getting in.

Steve started the engine, lowering the volume of the radio. He’d been listening to Accept of all things and Dustin nearly started screaming again because Steve Harrington did not listen to music like Accept.

“Well?” he prompted after a few minutes, “Are you gonna talk, or what?”

“I’m working up to it, alright?” Steve snapped, his hands gripping the steering wheel like a lifeline, his knuckles white.

“What’s there to work up to? You replaced me with Eddie. It’s fine.”

It wasn’t fine.

“That’s not – it’s not what you think, okay?”

“Then what is it?” Dustin demanded, turning in his seat to look at Steve properly, and Steve – Steve started laughing. “What’s so funny?”

Steve was laughing, definitely a little hysterical this time, his eyes wide and crazed. “I can’t believe this is my life.”

“Yeah. Well. You and me both,” Dustin muttered. He did feel a little calmer now, though, because Steve was clearly going through something here. Or maybe he had finally lost his mind.

Steve kept driving and the music kept playing and then Steve stopped driving and the music stopped playing and they were in the middle of nowhere and Steve was still white-knuckling the wheel and Dustin was starting to get seriously worried. But he waited.

“Alright,” said Steve, releasing a deep breath and the tension in his shoulders all at once. He let go of the wheel, reached into his pocket and pulled out a pack of cigarettes, lighting one of them. “I’ve worked up to it,” he announced.

“Great.”

“I’m sorry I haven’t been there, Dustin. I really am.” He sounded sorry, his eyes meeting and holding Dustin’s gaze, and Dustin almost felt a little guilty for shouting at him. “But I haven’t replaced you, okay?”

“Then why won’t you hang out with me anymore? Why won’t Eddie?” Dustin asked, “Like, I get that I’m younger than you, and maybe that’s boring, or whatever, but you didn’t care about that before, so I don’t understand why you care now, and if you did, I don’t understand why you couldn’t just tell me, instead of ignoring me.”

Steve was still looking at him, a series of emotions flickering over his face before settling on regret, and he took a long drag from his cigarette, waving the smoke away with his hand.

“Eddie and I are dating.”

Dustin blinked. Once. Twice. Three times. “What.”

“Eddie and I are dating.”
“See, I thought that’s what you said.” Not that it had made any more sense the second time around. “When the hell did this happen?”

Steve’s hand was trembling ever so slightly as he brought his smoke back up to his lips, his face now turned straight ahead. “Couple weeks ago.”

“A couple weeks?” Dustin asked, his voice rising a few octaves higher than he thought it could. “And I’m only hearing about this now?”

“Yes. Alright? Don’t be a dick about,” Steve said defensively, “We’re still figuring things out and we just wanted some time to ourselves to do that, and I didn’t even think I was – I didn’t think I could – that – and we’re dating, and you are literally the first person I’m telling about this, okay? Kind of, anyway. Eddie knows, obviously. And Robin, ‘cause she helped me figure some stuff out. And I think Eddie’s uncle might know ‘cause he keeps giving me these looks, but that’s not the point. The point is, you are my friend, you annoying little shit, and as my friend, I am telling you that I – you know.”

“That you have a boyfriend,” Dustin slowly filled in the blank, and Steve nodded.

“That I have a boyfriend,” he repeated, and now Dustin felt like a right ass because it wasn’t just Steve’s hand that was shaking but his voice as well.

“I’m sorry I yelled at you,” he said, “I guess I was just – I guess I was just jealous. I thought you’d replaced me.”

Steve glanced at him. “Henderson, it is literally impossible to replace you,” he said, looking and sounding a lot calmer now as he finished his cigarette, an almost-smile on his face. “So,” he drawled out, “We’re good?”

“Yeah.” Dustin nodded. “We’re good.”

“Good.” Steve started the car back up. The music made sense now, Dustin thought. “Hey, er, I was gonna swing by Eddie’s, if you – if you wanna hang out with us?”

“You sure?” Dustin asked, feeling a little self-conscious suddenly, but Steve rolled his eyes.

“’Course I’m sure,” he answered, pulling onto the road and driving back towards Hawkins, “He missed you, too, you know.”

“Guess I owe him an apology.”

“Guess you do.”

They arrived at Eddie’s trailer and the self-consciousness had transformed into actual nerves that made Dustin bite his lower lip. What if Eddie was actually angry with him? What if he’d messed up and lost one of the best friends he’d ever had? What if Eddie threw him out of the Party for not going to their last campaign? What if –

“Well, well, well. Look what the cat dragged in.” Eddie was lounging on the couch, his hair pulled up in a bun, wearing a worn-out Black Sabbath t-shirt with the sleeves cut off, and a sharp expression on his face. “You better be crawling on your knees, begging for forgiveness, if you wanna play D&D with us again, Henderson.”

Dustin froze where he stood while Steve walked past him and sat down close next to Eddie.

“Cut him some slack, Eddie,” he said, “Kid was upset, people do stupid shit when they’re upset.”

Some of the hard edges on Eddie’s face softened, his eyes widening. “Did something happen?” he asked, leaning forward as if he was ready to jump into action.

“No,” Dustin answered, “But I thought it did. I was wrong. I’m sorry.” It wasn’t much of an explanation, and Eddie questioningly looked back and forth between Dustin and Steve, waiting for either to elaborate. So, Dustin did, “Steve told me you’re dating,” he said, not missing the flash of surprise on Eddie’s face, “Which is cool, obviously, but I was jealous because you both kinda stopped hanging it with me.”

Understanding dawned on Eddie’s face, quickly morphing into his usual self-assured and slightly amused grin. “Well, we can’t have our child, our own flesh and blood, thinking his parents abandoned him, can we Lord Harrington?”

“We really can’t, Sir Munson,” Steve played along, and Dustin thought he may have accidentally entered a whole other alternate dimension of reality, but then Steve slid up the couch to make space between himself and Eddie and patted the cushions and Dustin stopped caring if this was Hawkins or the Leftside Right.

“Take a seat, Henderson,” said Eddie, “We’ll watch whatever movie you want.”

“Even an R-rated horror movie?” Dustin asked, sitting down between the two older boys.

“Oh, no, come guys –”

“Even an R-rated horror movie,” Eddie confirmed with no regard to Steve’s protests.

They did not end up watching a horror movie but the Life of Brian and Dustin didn’t even pay that much attention to the film anyway, too busy noticing Steve and Eddie holding hands behind his head and the way they were sharing a single can of Coke for some reason instead of just getting two. That was okay, though. He’d seen it before, after all, and he got to spent time with his two best friends again because, as it turned out, there had never been anything to be jealous of.

As much as Nancy hated to admit it, but learning that both Robin and Eddie were gay came as a surprise. Even more of a surprise was that Steve had apparently known about it and not cared. She was certain that the Steve she’d known back in school, the Steve she’d dated, would have had a very different reaction. Watching them now, though, all three sharing a beanbag in her basement, whispering and giggling and teasing each other, it suddenly hit her just how much Steve had changed. Sure, she'd seen it happening over the last few years, had seen the way he was with the kids, the way he was always there protecting the people around him, the first to jump in front of the bullet, but somehow it hadn't quite clicked until now. Steve was a different person. A good person.

It made her a little sad, in a way. Made her wish they could try again, maybe. But that wouldn't happen, she knew. They'd both moved on.

But she still couldn't quite shake the intrigue in this new Steve.

Watching him with Robin had filled her with a strange, rather irrational jealousy for reasons she couldn't explain. So sure had she been that they were secretly dating and simply not telling anyone about it. Looking at them now, Nancy had no idea how she could have ever thought something so outlandish. It was clear that they loved each other, sure, the same way Steve loved all the kids, the same way she loved Mike. It was a familial love, a deep-running, unconditional loyalty born out of shared trauma and too many sleepless nights. Platonic, with a capital P.

Eddie, though. Eddie was different. Of course, he was different, he was Eddie Munson. Nancy felt for him, really. Being pulled into their world of monsters and world-ending catastrophes, on top of being the main suspect for a murder he hadn't committed must have been terrible, and yet he’d stayed by their side and not left since. 

But Eddie was also different. Different with Steve. Nancy almost thought she was imagining it at first, but no. Eddie was flirting with Steve, Nancy was almost certain. His eyes crinkled in the corners and his smile turned just a little softer whenever he thought no one was looking and his eyes were trailing Steve wherever he went and his voice lilted just a little bit.

And the thing was, Steve didn't seem to care.

Quite the opposite actually.

Steve looked comfortable around Eddie, more comfortable than she'd seen him around anyone else, except for Robin, maybe, but it wasn't the same. Where Steve and Robin endlessly teased each other and apparently voiced their affections through insults, Nancy could have sworn she’d caught Steve blushing more than once after Eddie had called him honey or darling or sweetheart again, could have sworn she'd seen his eyes linger, could have sworn shed heard a familiar drawl to his words when talking to Eddie, the same drawl he'd had when talking to her. Back when.

Still. It was nice, being surrounded by people for once. Having a family again.

And it didn't seem to stop with Joyce and her two boys. While Jim had been busy breaking out of a Gulag, making it back to the States in one piece, and explaining how it was he was still alive, all the kids had apparently become even closer to each other and even found one or two new editions, like Jonathan's strange friend Argyle, or Eddie fucking Munson.

Jim knew Munson, was the thing, knew what he got up in the woods and in his van and at parties. He'd given him more than one warning over the years and would have liked nothing more than to send the useless, little piece of shit to rot in jail, if only so Jim wouldn't have to hear him and his stupid band again.

But that had been then.

These days, Jim wouldn't have cared if Eddie sold crack to middle-schoolers, because nearly dying for the fourth time in a row really did seem to put some things into perspective. Besides, Eddie actually seemed like an alright guy, all things considered, even if Jim would have rather gone back to Russia than admit that out loud. Not that he had to, mind, since no one ever asked his opinion on the matter. Munson was just there – driving the kids around in his beat up van, walking down the street with his arm around Robin Buckley’s shoulders, showing up to lunches and dinners and movie nights with the rest of the group as if he belonged there, that smug, impish grin always on his face and a glint in his eyes. At least he seemed to be doing his best to steer clear of Jim. 

He and Joyce had decided to go the fun fair they'd set up again in occasion of the end of summer break, this time without worrying about Russian Arnold Schwarzenegger, and as much as Jim hated to admit it, he was having a good time, actually. They hadn't gone on any rides yet, but he hadn't missed the way Joyce was eyeing the Ferris Wheel, and Jim was mentally preparing himself for that, when he spotted Steve and Munson from the corner of his eye at one of the booths. Munson was trying his hand at throwing darts at balloons and apparently doing quite well if the small crowd of children watching them in awe was anything to go by 

“How are you so good at this?” he heard Steve ask, just as Munson was about to throw another dart.

“I've been winning rigged games since before I could walk, princess,” Munson replied with confidence and took aim. The dart hit the balloon with a little pop, and the children cheered as the owner of the booth handed over a big, plush teddy bear to Munson who immediately offered it up to Steve.

“What am I supposed to do with this?” asked Steve, even though he'd already accepted it, hugging the teddy with both his arms.

Munson patted the teddy on its fuzzy head. “Cherish it with all your heart, Harrington.”

And, again, Jim wouldn't say this out loud under horrendous torture, but it was nice seeing them like this, happy and safe, after everything they'd gone through. After everything they'd all gone through.

And then things took a turn for the worse.

“You've got some nerve coming here,” a loud voice proclaimed, “Murderer.”

Jason Carver stood tall, looming over the children who quickly scattered, a group of Jason's friends flanking his shoulders, Tommy H among them.

Jim watched as Munson let out a heavy sigh before turning around, his teeth bared. “Long time no see,” he said, “Can't say I missed it.”

“You're not welcome here, freak.”

“And you,” Munson replied, taking a step forward and poking a finger into Jason's chest, “Are not the boss of me, pretty boy.”

Jason slapped his hand away, his face distorted in sheer hatred and disgust. “Don't touch me, fag.”

Munson raised his hands in mock surrender. “Methinks the jock doth protest too much,” he said, still grinning sharply as if he found the entire situation terribly amusing. Jim couldn't say he agreed. “You're a little obsessed with me, aren't you, Carver? I'm flattered, really, but, alas, it would just never work out between us.”

Jason looked like he was about to throw either throw up or throw a punch, and Jim got ready to step in, just in case. Steve, apparently, must have had the same idea, because he was stepping forward now, one hand laid on Munson's shoulder.

“Come on, Eddie, let's go.”

“Really, Harrington? You hang out with the freak now?” Tommy H sneered. Steve didn't react beyond rolling his eyes and gently steering Munson away, and Jim was just about to relax, when Tommy called after them.

“You better be careful, or people might get the wrong idea.”

“I think they'd get the right idea,” Jason said, “I think he likes taking it up the ass from the pervert.”

Steve snapped back around, walking up close to Jason. “What did you call him?”

“Steve, don’t –”

Jason smirked maliciously. “You heard. Pervert.”

Jim wasn't a 100% sure on who threw the first punch, but his money was on Steve, and he was almost ashamed to say that it took him a moment to react, too stunned by the two boys screaming and hitting at each in blind rage.

“That's enough,” he yelled, grabbing Jason by the shoulders and flinging him off Steve, against the side of the dart booth with a little too much force, maybe. “Walk away,” he warned the boy, standing protectively in front of Steve.

Jason scoffed, rubbing the blood off his face. “This isn't over yet,” he declared, finger pointed threateningly at Steve and Munson, but he did walk away.

“Alright everyone, show’s over,” Jim called out to the bystanders, glancing at Steve to make sure he didn't need an ambulance. The boy did look a little worse for wear, blood dripping from his nose and his lip, one eye already swollen, and his knuckles were clearly scrapped and bruised. Munson was supporting him, glaring at Jason's retreating back.

“Come on, let's get you cleaned up.” Jim took both boys to his car before going on a search for some water and a clean cloth.

Joyce was eerily silent next to him, her fists clenched.

“I'll get them something to eat and drink,” she announced curtly, not waiting for a response before stomping off and Jim watched her go.

When he returned to his car with a bowl of ice cold water and a cloth, Steve and Munson were sitting on the hood, their backs turned to him, a cigarette passing back and forth between their hands, and despite the noise coming from the fair, Jim could hear Munson's voice, clear as day.

“I don't need you to defend my honour, Steve.”

“You heard what he called you, right?”

“Yes. Yes, I heard. I'm not deaf. But getting into fights over it, isn't helping anyone. Least of all you.”

“Wasn't really thinking about me,” Steve muttered, running a hand through his hair and wincing a little.

Jim stood behind them, a little undecided and not wanting to intrude.

“I just –” Steve continued, “—I fucking hate it, okay? The way they treat you. It's not fair.”

“What, and you think I'm enjoying this?” Eddie asked rhetorically, “You think I like walking through town and people crossing the street the second they see me? I mean, don't get wrong, I've never been Mr. Popular, but this is different, because when they called me a freak and a fag, at least I knew where I was at and I could laugh it off because they had no idea how right they were, but this?” He shook his head, blowing out the smoke before handing the cig back to Steve. “I didn't kill Chrissy.”

Jim didn't miss the way Steve shifted closer until their shoulders touched, reaching out to take Munson's hand, nor the way Munson leaned into the touch, and he suddenly felt like he was in the wrong place at the very wrong time.

“They kinda have point though, y’know,” Munson muttered, “People are starting to talk. Wondering what golden boy Steve Harrington is doing with a schmuck like me.”

“Yeah well, fuck em.”

“That's the spirit.”

Jim made another attempt at coming closer, the bowl of water in his arms growing heavy, but apparently, Munson had other ideas.

“How are you doing?”

Steve shrugged, taking a drag of the cigarette and reaching up to his face. “It's just a few cuts and bruises. I've had worse.”

“That's not what I meant,” Munson responded, leaning forward a little to look right at Steve, and Jim took a step back again.

“I used to be like them,” Steve muttered, handing the cigarette to Munson and lowering his head, “I used to say those words and I mean them like they did.”

Munson took a drag, smoke spilling from between his lips. “I know,” he said casually, as if they'd been through that particular conversation before.

“I guess –” Steve huffed out a breath. “—I guess I just didn't realize how much it hurts, y’know?”

Munson hummed, finishing the cigarette and leaning back a little, his weight supported by one hand behind his back. “I could be a complete dick now and say something fucked up about karma and poetic justice, but I won't, because I like you and apparently I'm nice now.”

“Eddie Munson being nice?” Steve teased him, laughter in his voice, “Someone call the papers.”

“Hmm, headline practically rights itself.”

Jim decided he'd enough, then. Whatever moment the two boys had had, it was clearly over, and he really wasn't interested in lurking behind them for another hour, so instead he loudly cleared his throat and approached.

He caught Munson quickly letting go of Steve's hand and the flash of disappointment on Steve's face, but decided to ignore it.

“For your face,” him said, offering up the bowl and the cloth.

“Thanks,” said Steve, taking both, beginning to clean up his wounds, but Munson slapped his hands away and instead dipped the cloth into the water himself and delicately wiped the blood off Steve, while Jim watched, feeling just a little awkward. 

“So,” he prompted, hoping to alleviate some of the tension, “You into street fights now?”

“He deserved it,” Steve muttered, glancing at Jim from the corner of his eye, barely wincing as Munson dabbed the wet cloth against his split lip.

“Not gonna argue with you there, but, well, you should probably not make a habit of it.”

“Wasn't planning on it.”

“Good.” Jim nodded, folding his arms across his chest. “You should go see a doctor if you're starting to feel dizzy or nauseous.”

“Don't worry, I will,” Steve promised, turning his head to look at him, much to Munson's annoyance, “You don't have to, like, babysit us, you know. I've had worse.”

I know, Jim thought darkly, remembering Steve's face after Starcourt and the scar on his stomach.

“Alright,” he said instead, starting to back away just as Munson set aside the bowl of now bloodied water, wiping his hands on his jeans, his eyes fixed on Steve's face, and there was something about the look he was giving Steve that made Jim falter and stop. “Hey, uh –” He hesitated, debating with himself if he should really get involved in this. “—Hey, you boys gonna be okay?”

“We'll be fine,” Steve answered dismissively, “Like I said, I've had worse.”

It was a good out, and Jim almost took it, except Munson was looking at him now, a calculating expression on his face.

“That's not what I meant,” Jim echoed Munson's earlier words, and Steve stilled, his shoulders growing tense.

“We'll be fine,” said Munson the same calculating expression still on his face as if he was trying to see right through Jim's skull and into his brain. It reminded him a little bit of how El used to look at him, back in the beginning, all wide-eyed and suspicious.

“Well, if – If anyone else gives you any more shit about – about anything, you call me, alright? Being chief of police must be good for something.”

Munson still didn't look convinced, but Steve at least gave him a weak smile, his shoulders relaxing a little. “Thanks. Thanks, Jim.”

“Don't mention it, son.” Jim rubbed the back of his neck. “Just. Be careful out there. It's a shitty world.”

Steve opened his mouth as if to answer, but Joyce chose that moment to return with two comes of dripping ice cream.

“Sorry it took so long, there was a – a really long line.”

Steve's eyes grew wide as Joyce handed him one of the cones. “I – thanks, but –”

“Also, you're coming to dinner tonight.”

“No, no, you don't have to –”

“I insist. God knows your parents are never home and I doubt you cook for yourself.”

“He doesn't,” Munson chimed in, accepting his own ice cream with almost childish glee, “And we'd love to come by for dinner.”

“Dude.”

“What?” Munson shrugged at Steve “It's free food, man.”

Steve rolled his eyes, but he did thank Joyce again. “You really don't have to cook for me though.”

“I want to. You're family.”

That night, Jim found himself at a table that was too small for the amount of people sitting at it, but he wasn't complaining.

And when Max and Lucas started throwing peas at each other and half of them landed on the floor that he knew he would have to clean up afterwards, he didn't complain, and when Mike and Dustin started arguing about some comic, he didn't complain, and when Steve grabbed Munson's hand right there next to his plate for everyone to see, he smiled because Joyce was right. They were all family and he was alive and the people of Hawkins clearly didn't know what they were missing.
